articles.headline: Automakers Fear a New Normal of Low Sales
articles.snippet: The across-the-board decline in car sales is certain to put more pressure on the fragile finances of manufacturers.
articles.abstract: The across-the-board decline in car sales is certain to put more pressure on the fragile finances of manufacturers.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  The historic collapse of the new-car market dragged on in December, raising questions of whether the auto industry will ever again have sales levels that it took for granted just a few years ago.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: Bid to Revoke Madoff’s Bail Cites His Gifts
articles.snippet: Bernard L. Madoff tried to hide at least $1 million in assets from investigators, prosecutors told a judge.
articles.abstract: Bernard L. Madoff tried to hide at least $1 million in assets from investigators, prosecutors told a judge.
articles.lead_paragraph: Contending that Bernard L. Madoff sent at least a million dollars worth of jewelry as gifts to family members and friends last month, federal prosecutors asked a judge on Monday to revoke his bail and send him to jail.

articles.headline: Coming Down on Tobacco
articles.snippet: The new Congress plans to move aggressively against the tobacco industry by regulating cigarettes, raising sales taxes and ratifying an international antitobacco treaty.
articles.abstract: The new Congress plans to move aggressively against the tobacco industry by regulating cigarettes, raising sales taxes and ratifying an international antitobacco treaty.
articles.lead_paragraph: The new Congress plans to move aggressively against the tobacco industry in coming months by regulating cigarettes, raising per-pack sales taxes and ratifying an international antitobacco treaty, according to aides for key lawmakers and experts who expect the Obama administration to break a logjam on smoking issues.

articles.headline: As Prices Rise, Some See $2 Gas
articles.snippet: Gasoline prices have risen by several cents amid indicators that the national average could jump to $2 a gallon or higher this spring.
articles.abstract: Gasoline prices have risen by several cents amid indicators that the national average could jump to $2 a gallon or higher this spring.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON  The five-month slide in gasoline prices has come to an abrupt halt, with gasoline rising by several cents in recent days amid indicators that the national average could jump to $2 a gallon or higher this spring.

articles.headline: In Quiet Rebellion, Parishioners Keep Faith
articles.snippet: Parishioners have been guarding a church for 1,533 days so that the archdiocese cannot sell it.
articles.abstract: Parishioners have been guarding a church for 1,533 days so that the archdiocese cannot sell it.
articles.lead_paragraph: SCITUATE, Mass.  There are sleeping bags in the sacristy at St. Frances Xavier Cabrini Church and reclining chairs in the vestibule, but no one here gets too relaxed. “Please be ever vigilant!” a sign by the door warns, and the parishioners who have occupied the church since it closed more than four years ago take it as seriously as a commandment.

articles.headline: Panetta Is Chosen as C.I.A. Chief, in a Surprise Step
articles.snippet: The choice of Leon E. Panetta, a former White House chief of staff, to head the intelligence agency raised questions about his relevant experience.
articles.abstract: The choice of Leon E. Panetta, a former White House chief of staff, to head the intelligence agency raised questions about his relevant experience.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Leon E. Panetta, a former congressman and White House chief of staff, has been selected by President-elect Barack Obama to head the Central Intelligence Agency. The choice, disclosed Monday by Democratic officials, immediately revealed divisions in the party as two senior lawmakers questioned why Mr. Obama would nominate a candidate with limited experience in intelligence matters.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Carl Hulse

articles.headline: Air Security Could Involve Private Jets
articles.snippet: Some 10,000 air operators would lose at least some of their exemption status if a new security plan is adopted.
articles.abstract: Some 10,000 air operators would lose at least some of their exemption status if a new security plan is adopted.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of the biggest conveniences of private aviation is the speed with which passengers can get on the plane and off the ground.

articles.headline: Eating Crow at a Dinner for Wall St.
articles.snippet: Many heavy hitters on Wall Street, even those who did not get burned badly, should be glad that 2008 is history.
articles.abstract: Many heavy hitters on Wall Street, even those who did not get burned badly, should be glad that 2008 is history.
articles.lead_paragraph: Please, please take your seats. That includes you, Hank.

articles.headline: An Ex-Detainee of the U.S. Describes a 6-Year Ordeal
articles.snippet: Though never charged with a crime, Muhammad Saad Iqbal spent six years in American custody, during which he says he was taken to Egypt and tortured.
articles.abstract: Though never charged with a crime, Muhammad Saad Iqbal spent six years in American custody, during which he says he was taken to Egypt and tortured.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAHORE, Pakistan  When Muhammad Saad Iqbal arrived home here in August after more than six years in American custody, including five at the military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, he had difficulty walking, his left ear was severely infected, and he was dependent on a cocktail of antibiotics and antidepressants.
articles.byline: By Jane Perlez, Raymond Bonner and Salman Masood

articles.headline: Russia Cuts Gas, and Europe Shivers
articles.snippet: Russia’s gas price dispute with Ukraine escalated, disrupting deliveries to the European Union in the midst of a bitter cold spell.
articles.abstract: Russia’s gas price dispute with Ukraine escalated, disrupting deliveries to the European Union in the midst of a bitter cold spell.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Gazprom, the Russian gas monopoly, halted nearly all its natural gas exports to Europe on Tuesday, sharply escalating its pricing dispute with neighboring Ukraine. The cutoff led to immediate shortages from France to Turkey and underscored Moscow’s increasingly confrontational posture toward the West.
